key_title: Key to the species of Brassica

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Brassicaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Brassicaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1996). Brassicaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Upper stem leaves petiolate or narrowed to base
Upper stem leaves sessile, either bract-like or broad to stem-clasping at base, or upper part of stem leafless
Leaves and stem glabrous to very sparsely bristly; basal leaves with 1–3 lateral lobes; fruits not appressed
Basal leaves (at least underneath) and lower stem moderately to densely bristly
Fruit 1–2 mm wide, on 1–3 mm stalk beyond end of pedicel; biennial or perennial; basal leaves with 2–3 pairs of lateral lobes
Fruit 2–4 mm wide, terminating pedicel; annual; basal leaves with 1–2 pairs of lateral lobes
Basal leaves with 1–3 pairs of lateral lobes, bristly on both sides; fruit appressed, beak 1–3 mm long
Basal leaves with 4–10 pairs of lateral lobes, densely bristly below; fruit erect, beak 8–12 mm long
Basal leaves usually bristly, base of stem leaves clasped around at least half of the stem; filament of outer stamens curved at base
All leaves glabrous, base of stem leaves clasped around less than a third of the stem; stamens erect
First year rosettes grass green; inflorescence with open flowers equalling or overtopping the buds; petals 6–11 mm long, bright yellow
Leaves always glaucous; inflorescence with buds overtopping the open flowers; petals 11–14 mm long, pale yellow
